message_1: A radioactive element has a half-life of 30 years. If its initial mass is 500 grams, how much of it will be left after 90 years?
message_2:
To solve this problem, we can use the half-life formula:

Final mass = Initial mass * (1/2)^(time elapsed / half-life)

In this case, the initial mass is 500 grams, the time elapsed is 90 years, and the half-life is 30 years. Plugging these values into the formula, we get:

Final mass = 500 * (1/2)^(90 / 30)

First, we need to find the number of half-lives that have passed:

90 years / 30 years/half-life = 3 half-lives

Now, we can plug this value back into the formula:

Final mass = 500 * (1/2)^3

Final mass = 500 * (1/8)

Final mass = 62.5 grams

So, after 90 years, there will be 62.5 grams of the radioactive element left.
